question.title: Spring Security 6.5.0: Deprecation Warning authorizeRequests in XML-based Configuration
question.body:
I've recently updated Spring Security from version 6.4.4 to the latest version (6.5.0). Since the update, I'm consistently seeing the following warning in my logs:

[DefaultFilterChainValidator.checkAuthorizationFilters:128] Usage of authorizeRequests is deprecated. Please use authorizeHttpRequests in the configuration

My project exclusively uses XML-based Spring Security configuration, and migrating to Java-based configuration is currently not an option due to project constraints.

I've reviewed existing answers to similar questions, such as how-to-fix-spring-authorizerequests-is-deprecated, but they all focus on Java-based configurations and thus do not apply to my situation.

Furthermore, while the Spring Security documentation still provides examples for XML configuration (e.g., using <intercept-url pattern="/**" access="authenticated"/>), my understanding is that even these documented XML constructs are internally translated by Spring Security into the deprecated http.authorizeRequests()... pattern, rather than the recommended http.authorizeHttpRequests((authorize) -> authorize.anyRequest().authenticated()) pattern. This seems to be the root cause of the deprecation warning despite using the officially documented XML configuration.

I've also thoroughly checked the Spring Security 6.5.0 release notes and migration guides but couldn't find any specific information on how to address this warning within an XML-based setup, other than simply suppressing the warning.

Is there any way to resolve this authorizeRequests deprecation warning in an XML-based Spring Security 6.5.0 configuration without suppressing the warning or migrating to Java-based configuration?

answers.body: To avoid this warning when using XML-based configuration, you need to add use-authorization-manager="true" to the <http> block, as described in the Spring Security 5.x to 6.x migration guide.
